name: NewYorker
text: “As the protesters fled, I was left amid a swarm of angry officers in visors and helmets,” @embot writes. “A plainclothes officer in a T-shirt stopped, took a look at me, and, with great efficiency, doubled back and shoved me to the ground.” https://t.co/vWE5IA84JG

name: NewYorker
text: In 2017, Mark Bray outlined a history of how the Antifa movement encourages citizens to take action against Fascism, especially when the state fails to act. https://t.co/wy5UtzCuaJ

name: NewYorker
text: At this weekend’s protests in Houston, Texas, where George Floyd came of age, the air felt palpably charged, @brywashing writes: “You could reach out and grab the anger.” https://t.co/KgcagMWfnv

name: NewYorker
text: The writer, cook, and artist Tunde Wey discusses his recent essay, “Don’t Bail Out the Restaurant Industry,” and his radical vision for a more equitable culinary world. https://t.co/2gDB000dvj

name: NewYorker
text:
Analysts at a Washington-based think tank present a disturbing assessment of freedom in the United States.
https://t.co/iNO3Z4IdwI

name: NewYorker
text: During the pandemic, Vladimir Putin has periodically appeared on television to announce a series of rolling “non-working holidays,” leaving it up to individual regions to opt for lockdowns—or not—and declining to offer much in terms of economic relief. https://t.co/yDAXtA9EAG

name: NewYorker
text: Inside a volunteer-run network, organized by ordinary citizens, which hopes to supply health-care workers with the personal protective equipment they need to safely do their jobs. https://t.co/Zaa4f6GFNd

name: NewYorker
text:
In our latest podcast episode, a historian recalls the desperate measures taken to protect children from polio during an epidemic as frightening as our own. Listen here. #NewYorkerRadio
https://t.co/UM9lzpXOmu

name: NewYorker
text: Scenes from a weekend of mass protest in New York City: https://t.co/GgESx30RKq https://t.co/MhYAOc5b91

name: NewYorker
text: Almost 300 protesters were arrested in Atlanta this weekend. “I’ve never seen this in Atlanta,” one resident said of the demonstrations. “I guess it was a long time coming with our history here.” https://t.co/lxCd9mbh61

name: NewYorker
text: "When Tito died, in 1980, I was sixteen, and gleefully eager to partake in the unravelling of the socialist ideology, mainly because I found it oppressively boring," Aleksandar Hemon writes. https://t.co/ryIi3j54k7

name: NewYorker
text: “Naturally, the public conversation has begun to drift toward the question of what this moment means, and where we will go from here,” @brywashing writes. “But, at the end of the day, a man is dead.” https://t.co/6k7UijciKY

name: NewYorker
text: “ ‘But,’ Harvey interrupted, ‘what’s going to happen? They’re going to say I’m innocent, right? Not guilty. Isn’t that what you promised?’ ” A short story by Emma Cline. https://t.co/qMg8TIJHri

name: NewYorker
text: "Even now, after all that the country has endured in the past three and a half years, there are moments when it can feel as if we are wandering through a farce so bleak and implausible that it tests the mind," @eosnos writes. https://t.co/QLIVoKkeRp

name: NewYorker
text: RT @CondeNast: A message from employees at Condé Nast about why we are supporting #BlackLivesMatter: https://t.co/mBJ5GHoeEv

name: NewYorker
text: Why do we crave stories of sickness when so many of us are sick, or devising ingenious ways to remain non-sick? Anthony Lane on the shifting meaning of contagion films. https://t.co/giv2ASKYMW

name: NewYorker
text: In threatening to send troops into states that don't want them, Donald Trump has abused his power in yet another way, extending his legacy of lawlessness and authoritarianism, @JeffreyToobin writes. https://t.co/uKkGYxf2ZN

name: NewYorker
text: “I was soaking in the bath for the third time when the monkey slid the glass door open with a clatter and came inside. ‘Excuse me,’ he said in a low voice.” Read Haruki Murakami’s latest story in our Fiction Issue. https://t.co/kVIPxU8cSv

name: NewYorker
text: “We don’t have time to finger-wag at protesters about property. That can be rebuilt,” @aliciagarza said. “Target will re-open. The stores will re-open. That’s assured. What is not assured is our safety and real justice.” https://t.co/Q0ttBGUgkl

name: NewYorker
text: A previously unpublished story by Ernest Hemingway was recently found in the archives of the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library. Read it here, or in our latest Fiction Issue, on newsstands now. https://t.co/hAH4Czbocv
